_documentation.description: Literature standard reduction potentials (E°') for redox couples that eQuilibrator cannot calculate from group contribution methods. These are primarily metalloproteins (cytochromes) and quinones where the redox potential depends on the protein environment, not just chemical structure.
_documentation.problem: eQuilibrator uses group contribution methods that require atom-level structure (InChI). Cytochromes and other metalloproteins have no InChI because their properties depend on the protein fold and metal coordination, not the chemical formula alone. This results in ΔGf' = None and uncertainty = 100,000 kJ/mol.
_documentation.solution: Use eQuilibrator's RedoxCarrier class to inject literature reduction potentials. RedoxCarrier wraps a compound with a specified potential, and its get_stored_standard_dgf_prime() method returns -F×E (using n=1 internally).
_documentation.n_electrons_handling: IMPORTANT: RedoxCarrier always uses n=1. For multi-electron carriers (e.g., ubiquinone with n=2), the potential_mV field must be n × E°'. For ubiquinone: literature E°' = 45 mV, but we store 90 mV (2×45) so that -F×90mV = -8.7 kJ/mol = -nFE°'.
_documentation.convention: Potentials are given for the reduction half-reaction: Ox + ne⁻ → Red. The oxidized form is assigned E°' = 0 mV (reference), and the reduced form is assigned the effective potential (n × literature E°'). This ensures ΔGf'(red) - ΔGf'(ox) = -nFE°'.
_documentation.validation: Tested with r_0438 (Complex IV): Using cytochrome c E°' = 254 mV gives ΔG°' = -55.1 ± 0.8 kJ/mol. Manual calculation: (+24.5 from cyt c oxidation) + (-78.6 from O₂ reduction) = -54.1 kJ/mol. Agreement within 1 kJ/mol.
references: Berg, Tymoczko & Stryer, Biochemistry, 8th ed., Chapter 18
NIST Standard Reference Database 69: NIST Chemistry WebBook

cytochrome_c.name: Cytochrome c
cytochrome_c.description: Mitochondrial electron carrier between Complex III and Complex IV. Single heme c with Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ redox center.
cytochrome_c.reference: Voet & Voet Table 18-1; varies 220-280 mV depending on organism

cytochrome_b5.name: Cytochrome b5
cytochrome_b5.description: Microsomal electron carrier. Single heme b with Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ redox center. Involved in fatty acid desaturation and cytochrome P450 reactions.
cytochrome_b5.reference: Strittmatter & Velick (1956); varies -5 to +20 mV depending on source

thiosulfate_tetrathionate.name: Thiosulfate/Tetrathionate
thiosulfate_tetrathionate.description: Sulfur redox couple. S4O6²⁻ + 2e⁻ ↔ 2 S2O3²⁻. Used in iodometry and bacterial sulfur metabolism. Note: 2:1 stoichiometry - potential is per thiosulfate molecule (1e⁻ each).
thiosulfate_tetrathionate.reference: Kurth et al. (2015) JACS 137:13232-13235. Direct measurement by protein film electrochemistry.

ubiquinone_6.name: Ubiquinone-6 (Coenzyme Q6)
ubiquinone_6.description: Membrane-soluble electron carrier in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Shuttles electrons from Complexes I/II to Complex III. Yeast uses Q6 (6 isoprene units).
ubiquinone_6.note: Literature E°' = 45 mV, but RedoxCarrier assumes n=1. Use n×E°' = 2×45 = 90 mV to get correct ΔG = -8.7 kJ/mol
ubiquinone_6.reference: Voet & Voet Table 18-1; pH 7, membrane-bound form ~+45 mV

ferricyanide_ferrocyanide.reason: Artificial electron acceptor used in assays, not part of natural metabolism. KEGG IDs (C00176/C01352) may not match model IDs, causing incorrect calculations.
